Isabelle Tancioni

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/7432661634126142
  • Última atualização do currículo em 14/06/2019

Isabelle Tancioni é veterinária com mestrado e doutorado em Imunologia (USP). Em 2008, Dra. Tancioni iniciou seu pós-doutorado no Moores Cancer Center/ Universidade da Califórnia San Diego (UCSD) e seus resultados foram fundamentais para promover os inibidores da FAK para o teste clínico em humanos. Dra. Tancioni tem como objetivo fazer significantes contribuições para avanços no processo de descoberta e desenvolvimento de novas drogas para câncer de mama entre outros, usando abordagens que podem beneficiar humanos e animais. Assim como nas mulheres, o câncer de mama é o câncer mais frequentemente diagnosticado em cadelas, especialmente em países como o Brasil e Portugal, onde as cadelas não são castradas em idade precoce. Dra. Tancioni é veterinária de uma área onde o câncer mamário em cães tem uma alta prevalência, um dos seus objetivos é promover o conceito de One Medicine com foco na pesquisa do câncer, resultando na implementação de avanços na pesquisa biomédica para o benefício de ambos humanos e medicina veterinária. Importante, como seres humanos, os cães morrem devido a metástases, e novos tratamentos são necessários para controlar a doença metastática em ambas as espécies. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2017 - Atual
Associação de Veterinários Veganos e Vegetarianos (VEG VETS)
Descrição: The VEG VETS ? Vegan and Vegetarian Veterinarians Association is an initiative to create the first network of vegan, vegetarian and veggie-friendly veterinarians in Brazil, a country with more than 290 veterinary schools, almost 10 times as many as the US. This project connects veterinarians and students willing to oppose the animal exploitation status quo related to the veterinary profession. Most people choose to be veterinarians to help and protect animals. However, the practice of veterinary medicine involves alarming contradictions when it comes to treatments and services provided to pets vs farm animals. Starting in college, students are taught to consent to the exploitation of farm animals, with the goal of increasing profits for the animal agriculture industry. While students learn to treat pets as sentient beings, they are taught to see farm animals as merely tools. This project aims to inspire and embrace those veterinarians and students who are vegan, vegetarian and veggie-friendly. The project is committed to raising awareness and supporting students and professionals through information sharing and discussions about relevant science-based content, exposing the contradictions of veterinary practice, as well as building their capacity to spread the word and generate impact in their communities..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Isabelle Tancioni - Coordenador / Silvia Neri Godoy - Integrante.
2011 - 2017
Testing the role of non-canonical FAK signaling in the nucleolus of breast cancer cells
Descrição: Breast cancer is the second highest cause of cancer-related death and the most frequent cancer diagnosed in women world-wide. A primary complication of breast cancer is metastasis (tumor spread to distant sites). While the five-year breast cancer survival rate for women with localized breast cancer is 98%, this drops to 27% for women with distant organ metastasis. I have been working with a group of researchers on the development and pre-clinical testing of a small molecule inhibitor to a protein called focal adhesion kinase (FAK). During breast cancer progression, FAK expression is elevated, and this is correlated with poor patient prognosis. Focal adhesion kinase (FAK) is a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase that controls cell proliferation and survival downstream of integrin receptors and regulates mammary stem cells. The evaluation of mammary stem cells in vitro is performed using 3D cultures, where cells are placed on dishes with non adhesive surface. Under deprivation of anchorage signals, FAK is translocated to the nucleus. The nucleolus, a non-membrane structure within the nucleus, is important in the control of ribosome biogenesis, regulates the sequestration of nuclear proteins, and increased nucleolar size is a marker of aggressive tumors. Nucleostemin, a nucleolar-localized protein, acts to modulate cell cycle progression and and stemness. I hypothesize that FAK regulates nucleostemin expression in tumor cells, impacting tumor progression. Although many drugs have low efficacy on tumor cells cultured in 3D cultures, nanomolar small molecule FAK inhibitor (PF-271 or PND-1186) addition can prevent anchorage-independent growth of tumor cells as spheroids through mechanism(s) that remain unresolved..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Isabelle Tancioni - Coordenador.
2008 - 2017
Role of FAK in regulating integrin and extracellular matrix expression in ovarian cancer spheroids.
Descrição: Ovarian cancer is the leading cause of gynecological cancer mortality worldwide, resulting 15,000 deaths per year in the USA. The main contributor to the high mortality rate is its unusual mechanism of dissemination. In ovarian cancer tumor cells are shed from the primary tumor into the peritoneum where they float as clumps of aggregated cells, called spheroids. Currently, the majority of treatments are ineffective in preventing spheroid growth and dissemination since spheroids have been shown resistant to common chemotherapeutics. Chemotherapy does not inhibit anchorage- and vascular-independent growth associated within a 3D (three-dimensional) structure. Thus, new methodologies that specifically target spheroid-mediated disease progression need to be developed. Tumor spheroids are the most likely source of metastatic spread and recurrent disease, thus, it is important that researchers determine how FAK functions at the molecular level and this knowledge be applied to determine cause-effect relationships with regard to clinical treatment outcomes. This better understanding of the role of FAK in spheroid biology will identify new treatment opportunities for the sustained treatment of metastatic disease. General aim: The main goal of this proposal is to test a new hypothesis as to how FAK may function to promote tumor metastasis. For this, we are evaluating how FAK regulates integrin and osteopontin expression in ovarian cancer spheroids..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Isabelle Tancioni - Coordenador.
